clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Opticell Ag on Split-Thickness Skin Graft Donor Sites in Adult Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Opticell Ag (Chitosan Based Dressing) on Split-Thickness Skin Graft (STSG) Donor Sites in Adult Subjects

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this single center, prospective case series is to evaluate the effective management of split-thickness skin graft donor site wounds using Opticell Ag (Chitosan-based dressing).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed up to 14 days of use
primary_outcome.description: Pain reported by Subject using a visual analog scale (VAS)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed up to 14 days of use

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed up to 1 month of use
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed using the Vancouver scar scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed up to 14 days of use
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by investigators using a 5-point Likert Scale up to 14 days of use

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed up to 1 month of use
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by investigators using a cost analysis of the treatment comparing all dressings up to 1 month of use

arm_group.description: Opticell Ag covered with a transparent occlusive dressing (Tegaderm) with evenly distributed perforations which permit a controlled leakage into a layer of cotton gauze pads placed directly over the Opticell Ag and occlusive dressing combination.

intervention.other_name: Opticell Ag Plus Gelling Fiber with Silver

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Inpatient status at study site
- Subject must be receiving a split-thickness skin graft (STSG)
- Wounds must not exceed 10% total body surface area (TBSA)
- Any donor site
- Ability to comply with necessary wound care/follow up
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subject is pregnant
- Subject has been diagnosed with Diabetes
- Subject is a smoker
- Subject takes steroids
- Subject is sensitive and/or allergic to shellfish and/or silver
- Wounds that exceed 10% total body surface area (TBSA)
- Inability to comply with necessary wound care/follow up

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Surgery, Harvard Medical School, Division of Plastic Surgery
